text: Thank you and good afternoon, everybody.

The time is 2:03.

Councilmember Herbold.
Councilmember Herbold.

If there is no objection the minutes of February 7, 2022 will be adopted.
Hearing and seeing no objection the minutes are now adopted.
Let's go to the Presidents report.
On today's agenda we will hear from our office of Intergovernmental relations, why are focused on the proposed state transportation package.
Councilmember Herbold will propose a proclamation.
Surrounding the Unreinforced masonry.
As a reminder, tomorrow, the Mayor will be at our council meeting to deliver the state of the city address to the Council and the public at large.
We anticipate the state of the city address will be approximately 25 minutes.
And will be our opportunity to hear from our new Mayor and his perspective and priorities of his new administration.
We will go to item number three and that is the state legislative session update, Oir.
I will handed over to Gael Tarleton.
Thank you Council President.
And members of the city council.
We are here today to not only celebrate Valentine's day, but to celebrate the impending fiscal cut off in the house and Senate tomorrow at 5:00 P.M.
Our state relations director, Quinn Majeski and are state lobbyists, Elsa Brwon will give you an update on major pieces of activity the last few days and today.
In the Council briefing was sent to you last night and Council received from Quinn Majeski a summary of the move ahead Washington, which we will go into shortly.
I will turn it over to you.
Thank you members of the Council and happy to be here today.
We are coming up tomorrow at 5:00 P.M.
On the House of origin cut off.
As a reminder, that is the deadline that bills have to move out of the Chamber from which they originated.
House bills have to be passed out the house for an Senate has to be passed off the Senate floor.
We are closely tracking a number of bills that are of interest to you and to the city and we will go into those in a little bit.
I want to provide a couple of high-level updates before we do that . First the revenue forecast, the States revenue forecast will be coming out with an update on Wednesday, the 16th.
That is going to corsage the release are update of the proposals for the operating capital and transportation budgets and we are expecting to see those either later this week, or early next week.
Those will come out and will be monitored closely and we look for items of interest and items of impact to the city.

And also, something we have you have been closely monitoring, last Tuesday, just after Council briefing the house and Senate transportation shares released a new transportation revenue package proposal.
I will go over some of those details now.
I will start by saying, we have been talking about this and the Legislature has been talking about this for several years now.
Some changes in legislative Dynamics occurred during the interim, most notably changing the Senate transportation share.
Senator Hobbs got promoted to be the new Secretary of state.
And Senator Leah has stepped into his role as transportation share.

I think that combined with other Dynamics allow for the house and Senate to align more closely on the proposals . You may recall in previous years the house had their proposal and the Senate had their version.
This year they have jointly come together to release a proposal which I think speaks to some real movement and a better chance of something getting done this year.
The proposal has changed somewhat.
From one we have reviewed previously.
It is smaller in scope and we are looking at $16.8 billion package, which sounds large but the proposals last year or 18 to 28.
Úthis is scale down.
Most notably the Scaling down has come by removing any new increase to the gas tax.
That was a major component of previous proposals and that has been removed.
Instead, legislators are relying primarily on revenues derived from the climate commitment active that was passed last year and that is the States new cap an invest program.
Predominantly relying on those revenues, $5.4 billion . They are also assuming $3.4 billion in funding from the reauthorization of the service transportation act at the Federal level.
And there is a proposal to institute a new tax on exported fuels.
Feels exported out of the state and that would bring us to billion dollars.
There is a one-time transfer from the operating budget to the transportation budget of $2 billion and there is a Smorgasbord of increases to various fees, raising just north of $1 million.
That is the summary of the revenue side.

On the spending side there has been some chips and changes, most notably the proposal that was put forward has more money than previous proposals . and more money than any revenue package we have seen in the States history, put toward finding.
Transit, bike, green transportation and Electrification.
That is all funding booked from the climate commitment act in that is about $5.4 billion in total.
New increased, state grants that the city would be competitive for.
The remainder of the package, in the past I have described it as highway spending but what it really is is the 18th amendment restricted which means it has to be spent on certain sources.
I make that distinction now because it is not really dedicated to highways in the way we have understood it to be in the past and seen it to be in the past.
There is about $3 billion in maintenance and preservation which is a sizable investment from the States part.
There is $2.4 billion for fish passage barriers and the States Covid obligation.

And there is some funding for new projects within the 18th amendment restricted account and there is some spending I want to highlight that would impact the city of Seattle through the Washington D.O.T.
Programs or directly on Seattle projects . The most substantial, a lot of the transportation revenues have been declining since the pandemic, wears of the revenues have bounced back.
And number of projects from the connecting Washington 2015 transportation revenue package have been experiencing shortfalls.
This proposal would Backfill a lot of those shortfalls including the state route 520 West and project.
Which is within the city of Seattle.
That would receive $406 million in Backfill . in terms of new projects, there is $50 million Bookmark for pedestrian safety improvements.
$25 million for the transportation corridor system improvements.
And 500,000 booked for the pedestrian improvements in white center.
I will pause and see if there are any questions I want to save time for updates with regards to the bills we are tracking for you.
Before we go to Councilmember Pedersen, this was attached to the memo we got from Oir, the last two pages.
It outlines the whole $16.8 billion and thank you for going through those.
The things you mentioned were exactly what I was going to mention.
The North Aurora safety improvement.
I am excited that the tribes, they have transit and mobility grants . I don't know if I have seen that before.
I will handed over to Councilmember Pedersen.
He has it.
Thank you Council President Juarez.
And thank you to your team and the briefing as well.
I know a lot of us are excited about the democratic state Transportationpackage and the projects you mentioned like 520 and Aurora and et cetera.
For context, the 16 billion that is spread out over 16 years, is that correct?
That is correct.
Thank you for clarifying that.
It is a 16 year proposal.

Of the sources of funds in the two resources bills, House bill and Senate bill, of that 16 billion spread out over 16 years are there any sources that are more at risk than others? and if those sources don't come through, do we know how the state would Prioritize the $16 billion they are spending?
I think they have uncertainty attached to them for a variety of reasons.
The exported fuels tax and the one-time transfer from the general fund.
That is obviously, not an insubstantial amount of the package.
They are each $2 billion.
Combine will be about $4 billion.
Unfortunately, Councilmember, we don't really know necessarily what they would cut it for some reason those don't make it across the finish line.
We are advocating on behalf of the city's interest and I think if those don't have sufficient support within the Legislaure, we will see a revised proposal before something is passed.
But Obviously, the chair is including it and it would indicate it has at least some support and ability to pass.
If slightly Shakier than other elements.
Thank you.
There is a policy change in the legislation allowing for utilities to potentially be increased.
As I understand it, in reading the legislation it would not impact Seattle city light and it would not impact Seattle public utilities . is that correct?
The proposal contemplated includes a handful of new revenue options for cities.
They would receive the authority to implement . One will be a .1% sales tax, similar to the existing authority.
The other would be a new 2% tax on a select utilities.
I believe this is, in the document that was sent this is listed as, all utilities, except electricity.
We have actually--they have been rolling out information in official language on these bills throughout the week and we have some additional clarity.
It would just be three specific utilities.
And that would be natural gas, steam and telephone.
It would not impact our municipal utilities at the city.
And I would note, that 2% tax, if the package were to pass, that would be an authority that the city would gain and need to make a decision about whether or not to impose.
It would not be imposed on us.
Thank you.
Last question, my favorite topic is bridges.
I appreciate you highlighting a couple of bridge items.
That are important to us.
It looks like it is still not much for bridges and I don't see the I-5 bridge to North Seattle.
I don't see that.
That has concrete liberally falling from the belly of the bridge . on a couple of parks.
How would that be funded? for Washington D.O.T.
To fix that.
I don't see that listed separately.
There is no specific call out for any sort of work on I-5 in that area you are Referencing, Councilmember.
I will say that the $3 billion in maintenance and preservation, that funding could go toward that and that is something we report to work with Washington D.O.T.
On that.
If it is passed on the implementation on where those dollars are going.
Other any more questions for Quinn regarding this piece?
I am not seeing any.
Gael, do you want to keep walking us through this?
Thank you.
Yes, indeed.
We will have Elsa give you as much up-to-date input on the moving train that is happening in Olympia virtually and physically right now.
Go ahead, Elsa.
Quinn usually covers transportation but I will mention a few bills we have seen move forward already.
One is 5707 which would extend our automated traffic camera enforcement pilot.
I think I am encouraged with that one.
We have another bill we are supportive of that would create more ease and renewal of the transportation benefit district.
There is a limit on the number of times the city can renew that authority.
This would eliminate that sunset.

We are encouraged to see both of those move out of the Senate . Another bill that a number of you have been following that we have been working on for quite some time is related to--for tiny House villages.
And clarifying city authority around those exemptions.

We saw that move out of the Senate which was very encouraging and we will work with House members on how to strengthen that policy in the house . Some of the big city priorities have already moved, which is nice to have that happen.
It uses your mind as you approach cut off.
A few other bills in the housing space that we are followed for some time.
Maybe this bill has not been briefed this year but came up last year which is 1099 which would add climate change response to the States comprehensive planning framework.
That came out of the house and we are encouraged to see the bill move out.
Another bill that moved out of the housing space is apple homes for house which would provide continuity for Medicaid community supports and we are encouraging support of that bill this year.
Some of you have caught up with our team on that one.
Some bills Weare awaiting action on.
Something I think many of you have indicated that you are interested in following is 1782, the governor's housing proposal.
That bill is awaiting a vote in the house . It has been pulled to the floor calendar but we have not seen it on the run list yet.
We will follow that bill closely.
And watch for a floor vote on that bill.
I think the other bill that some of you have been tracking closely is 1904.
The rental notice bill requiring notice to Renters about increases and their rent above 7%.

That bill is on the House second reading and it has not received a floor vote . We will watch that and provide you with a more comprehensive update next week about bills that have made it through cut off or have not made it . I think maybe the final section that I would touch on quickly is on public safety.
Many of you have been following updates to use of force legislation.

There has been movement on those bills . The Senate bill, 5919, which would modify the standards for use of force in a number of areas including establishing the definition of use of force and authorizing some vehicular pursuits, passed out of the Senate last week.
Fan a House bill, 2037, which has somewhat more limited reach and the Senate version has also passed off the floor.
Both of those bills are continuing through the process.
And have received a floor vote.
Thank you.
Council President, that concludes our report.
But we are happy to take questions.
And comments and any other concerns.
I know you said this in the memo.
But can you briefly, for the viewing public, rattle off the dates for when the cutoffs are and when session ends?
Happy to do that.
It is House of origin cut off tomorrow on February 15.
Things move pretty quickly after that . On February 24 we will have the House policy cut off.
That is when bills who made it over will have to make it out of the Senate policy committee or static policy committee.
On February 28 we have the fiscal cut off.
Those bills that make it out of policy committee will have to make it out of a fiscal committee.
On March 4 we have the House cut off where bills have to make it off the opposite House floor.
There is still time after that which could be mysterious.
Sometimes when a bill makes it over it is amended in the opposite house.
A House bill made it through the committee but in the Senate committee there are further changes.

From March 4 on there is a process of reconciling the differences . seeing if there is agreement on bills that have passed from the house and Senate on what will become law or if there is not agreement, will not make it through the process.
March 10.
This is an even year.
That means the House starts on the house under the Senate side?
Bills.
They always start on both sides.
Confusingly.
They will both cross over after House of origin cut off.
Okay.
Is there anything else, Gael or Elsa, before we say goodbye?
I think I see Councilmember Mosqueda.
I don't see her anymore.
Sorry, Madam President I don't have my virtual Handout.
I had my real Handout.
I apologize.
I wanted to follow up on the question.
Perhaps the question was whether the budget is originating from the house or the Senate, depending on the year.
In the biennium year it trades back and forth.
Whoever introduced it in the biennium year, I think it was the Senate in 2021.
The House will introduce it in the next year.
There is a likelihood that the house and Senate operating budgets will come out about the same time.
That is what we have been told.
In 2023 it will matter a lot and I think the House--if I am remembering from 2021 and Quinn correct me if I am wrong, they flip back and forth in the biennium year.
That is what I was getting at.
I think the Supplementals are so closely aligned and the revenue forecasts as Elsa mentioned is coming out on the 16th.
They are ready to move, as soon as the revenue forecast comes out.
They will both want to come out pretty much the same time.
I don't know which sides bill number will carry the budget.
I don't know that.
Okay.
They may know that.
I don't know.
I just want to thank you.
All three of you.
For providing us and breaking down every week, now we are at nine topic issues in which bills have hung on a which are gone now.
I've gone from comparing week to week and I can see where things are falling off . Thank you for that.
Council President, Federal affairs for all of you.
It looks like there will be a continuing resolution and there is an effort to actually get an appropriations bill outs sometime in May.
An extraordinary thing could happen in Congress . We might actually have officially approved budget and not just a continuing resolution.
That is according to today's report from our Federal lobbyist next week, we will see what happens.
You mean the build back better, breaking into pieces?
It is in negotiation again.
In pieces?
Not necessarily.
Okay.
You know more than I do.
As of today.

Give me a call.
Call me.

For a year on Valentine's day, the National Trust for historic property, I'm sorry.
The National Trust for historic preservation spreads love for historic places through what is called a heart bombing campaign.
Hard bombing is the Act of showering and older or historic place with tangible expressions of affection and devotion.
Today's proclamation recognizes the significant cultural and architectural Unreinforced masonry buildings that are some of Seattle's most beloved community gathering places.
These are the sweethearts and the Icons of many neighborhoods.
On this Valentine's day that Council is pledging its Adoration for our architectural and cultural past while Reimagining the future, with safe, Seismically upgraded masonry buildings.
This afternoon my office forwarded on someone pages from historic Seattle on TV, Unreinforced masonry buildings for each district.
And the city as a whole for the At-Large Councilmembers.
And the proclamation it sells, Alex in my office B7 last week.
And tomorrow you, historic Seattle and the group will join us for a presentation directly following the Mayor state of the city speech.
I hope you can join me in Affixing your signature.

Heart bombing is the Act of showering and older or historic place with tangible expressions of affection and devotion.
Maybe I could tell my spouse that and I will get some jewelry out of this.

This week the lineup is starting with Councilmember Strauss and then it will go to Councilmember Herbold, Councilmember Lewis, Councilmember Morales, Councilmember Mosqueda, Councilmember Nelson, Councilmember Pedersen, Councilmember Sawant in the myself . Councilmember Strauss.
Thank you Council president and colleagues.
Welcome to today.

Last week in district 6 I continue to hold operational coordination meetings with community leaders, governmental entities and nongovernmental entities to make interventions to address homelessness in specific places in district 6.
This work continues and if you'd like to meet with me status updates, more information or receive assistance do so during office hours.

Last week I met with collision about safety and improvements we could make to the brewery district . Last Saturday I joined the mother of a 15-year-old boy his body was pulled from Seattle's green Lake last July.
She and committee members canvassing the park and neighborhood to see if anyone may have information about what happened in his last hours of life.
There are many questions that are left unanswered.

If you there between July 2 and 14 of 2021, they are asking for you to look at photos and videos to see if he was in the background or if there is information that may be helpful to the investigation.
You can contact his family Údirectly.
Or reach out to my office and we will put you in touch.
On Sunday I jury joined the litter patrol . The organizers meet every Sunday morning at 8:45 at the Bathhouse parking lot.
They have vests and bags.
All you have to do is show up.
I want to thank the volunteers who helped make it a successful event and to the organizers for making it happen every weekend.
Last week in district 6 I hosted office hours on Thursday.
And met with four people from East Ballard and several others.
I think almost every meeting discussed homelessness, a traffic circle request was only one meeting.
Public safety, Land-Use and neighborhood vibrancy and zoning at large.
I want to thank everyone.
This week office hours on Thursday from 2:00 until 6:00 P.M.
This week in district 6 we are hosting a meeting focusing on where the industrial and commercial areas border.
To make a meaningful intervention into some of the issues that are occurring.

This week I will attend the board legislative steering committee meeting and I will be joining the Fremont Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday and attend a regional transit committee afterwards . last week, citywide, I met with the Mayor and we had a great discussion and we are Partnering on projects and I look forward to working with him and his entire team on many things . I was able to meet with the interim budget director . as many of you have heard through your briefings, we received the overview briefing regarding the current fiscal situation that is looming.
I also was able to meet with Patrick, the executive director of Weld Seattle.
The program is highly successful by utilizing vacant buildings and homes that are set to be demolished . If you want to know more Nova vacant building to be used, look them up.
I was also able to meet last week with Puget sound regional Council to discuss the transportation policy board.
It is great to partner with you to get the infrastructure needs met Lastly, I attended the meeting of the transportation policy board.
Council President Juarez is going this my diary.
And thank you for letting me do this.
Most importantly, in the land use committee there is one item on tomorrow's agenda.
Council bill which extends for Úsix months temporary Floodplai regulations.

A vote on a quasijudicial Rezone of the property of Roosevelt way northeast.
Everything in public hearing on the first Hill Tdr legislation.
Council president and colleagues, are there any questions?
Seeing no further questions.
I am excited to announce Councilmember Herbold is back.
I am excited to pass it off to Councilmember Herbold.
Thank you so much.
I am back but I am still off camera.
Hopefully, I will continue with my healing.
I appreciate all the well wishes I have received.
And I want to thank Councilmember Lewis for filling in for me last week and stepping up to chair the public safety and human services committee.
That was very kind and needed.
And I really appreciate that.
To present the basic law--I'm sorry.
The Pre-Basic law enforcement training starting in the spring.
You may recall that the Council supported the training.

One part about this training, it is not just the content and how it is designed to give recruits meaningful exposure to the unique immunities they will be serving in the organizational culture of SPD and to give them the foundation before they enter the standardized statewide training.
Normally students are on the Department payroll for months before they begin their formal training at the state Academy.
And this training curriculum that the chief has developed, make sure that while they are on the city payroll, we are working to get the more exposure to the communities of Seattle.
I really appreciate that.
There is no meeting next week.

For next week's meeting, I just want folks to know that the year and crime report went out last week . We Miss the opportunity to hear it in our committee last week that we have been invited to present on the year end report.

Had because of some of the conversations that have happened in last week's economic development committee and work that Councilmember Lewis and I have been doing, we invited SPD to come and talk about the existing retail theft program.
Some other public safety items, the Mayor's office let me know last week that they will share the proposed policy on the second week of March.
There is a lot of public interest in the new SPD policy on dishonesty and that is where the policy is held within the policy manual.
It is the dishonesty policy and I appreciate the opportunity that the executive and the Department are giving it an opportunity to get it finalized.
I saw a letter which included the Council's amendments . code says the Council shall endeavor to act.

This is on the word endeavor on any mayoral emergency within 48 hours . The Council, they modify the executive order so we could limit it . is no funding for this program . Council was in full agreement to look at the needs of other departments for hiring bonus programs.
The action that the Council did was to authorize spending during 2021.
And making available $500,000 in bonuses for 2021. you may recall there were proposals for providing funding . On December 30 at 6:00 P.M.
The former Mayor sent a letter.
Saying they don't have to adhere to the changes to the executive order.
And the changes are not effective.
The city attorney's office did not provide this advice.
The Mayor's office quickly directed the Department--I am working with the Mayor's office on addressing the issue related to the fact that in January--joined the Bash and were offered bonuses.
The Council adopted a request for a--with the request of the date of March 1. I want to thank the Mayor for the transparency and cooperation.
On the human services, the results . The Rfp provided about--to find Reentry services.
[Indiscernible-Audio cutting out] where we were well represented by Council President Juarez.
We received 26 proposals totaling--was comprised of community members and staff.
There were 10, I'm sorry, there were nine proposals recommended for funding.
And received funding and those organizations include Sierra Club, boys and girls Club, arms around you, East Africa committee services, and the University beyond bars.

And I want to note that as far as--I will be attending the board of health meeting on Thursday where we will vote on a repeal of the--experienced by--. We will be connecting a resolution in support of helmet use.
And that is all I have today.
Do you have any questions or comments?
Seeing none it looks like I am passing it on to Councilmember Lewis.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Herbold.
Good to be with you this afternoon.
Everything will be fairly brief.
In keeping with what would be expected, I would hope.
The committee agenda for this coming Wednesday, February 16.
Of public assets and homelessness committee.

We will be hearing a presentation from the climate pledge arena to give us an update on how the programming has been going so far and closing the Loop on the impressive process, engineering and everything that went into creating the really critical facility come here at the Seattle center.
Looking forward to that opportunity to hear from the team . We will be considering several Commission appointments to the Seattle parks and recreation Commission.

On the March 2 Council for committee meeting for homelessness and public assets and homelessness, I hope right now is to see if we can get an update from the just care team which has not presented to the Council for several months.
But we try to check in with them on a quarterly basis.
At least on my previous committee of homeless investments and assets.
Hopefully on March 2, we can get an update from the just care team on things have been going.
And the other areas they have been working in including Chinatown as well as little Saigon . over the course of the last couple of months.
What the horizon of that program looks like as it is currently anticipated to wind down in June.
And what ways we can presume your of and expand the capacity or buy it more time.
Given we are in a transition period.
It will be interesting to hear what lessons we have learned and what we might be able to do, to help out with the looming deadlines as it relates to just care.
And they generously agreed to come on March 2. I believe deputy Mayor Washington will be available as well to talk about how we might move forward as a city family and address those issues.
Moving on to some of the departments under the public assets committee . I am happy to give the weekly report from clean cities.
Between January 31 and February 5, the queen city initiative removed the 3103 needles and collected 6000 pounds of trash from 35 encampment locations.

We will continue to monitor the queen city initiative which has been stepping up its game throughout the first quarter of this year and transmitting statistics for breathing every week so we can share with members of the Council.
Library updates.
The Seattle public library submitted information that the windows at the Madison and Seattle central locations have been Vandalized.
Have been fixed.
Patrons can go to those locations and no longer see windows that have been damaged by vandalism.
I appreciate the library for sending that update along to indicate the work order was completed.
We know that at least in the case of central library of vehicle had driven into the building.
In March 2021.
And caused considerable damage.
And the two Finalists for chief librarian were interviewed last week.
And the board of trustees is expected to make final decisions in late February or early March, regarding who will be our new chief librarian.
I appreciate members of the public that are tuning in and weighing in on the critical decision.
As we look forward to replacing the last permanent library and, who moved on to new opportunities.
Finally, I want to recognize the announcement today from Expedia . In my district.
That Expedia will be reopening starting officially on April 4.
Along with a similar announcement from Microsoft which will be returning to a hybrid work on their campus in Redmond.

It is really great to hear that Expedia, which put so much time and resource coming over from the East side to build out the old campus and really develop that into a big robust and activated campus . It is good to hear they're going to make the decision to come back on April 4 and give a big vote of confidence to us in the city.
That campus employs 3000 people who will come back to work.
Either full-time on campus or in a hybrid posture.
It is a great vote of confidence as we expect to have more firms making announcements that they will return to work.

I am pleased to see this great neighborhood returning . and validating the decision that Expedia made to relocate from the East side to Seattle and take advantage of that opportunity . I know they just finished up before Covid and they did not have much time to move in.
I hope now they can make full use of that location . I look forward to seeing that return to work from Expedia and looking forward to other companies following the example.
And I look forward to our work as a Council in the city government and the investments and the strategy necessary to ease and support the decision of firms to return to work in the coming months.
With that, Madam President, I don't have anything further and I landed over to Councilmember Morales . and was there any questions.
Otherwise, I will hand it over to Councilmember Morales.
Thank you very much.
Good afternoon.
I want to let you know that there are no items for my committee.
Last week the neighborhood education arts and civil rights committee met.
We had a briefing from the arts Department on their current grant programs and we did vote to recommend confirmation of two human rights Commission report minutes.
I believe those will be coming next week.
To full council.
We also received a briefing from the Department of education and early learning on the Rollout of their youth led social got justice grant.
There was a technology issue that resulted in dozens of students receiving notification that they had been awarded grants when they had not.
I want to thank the director and his team for being responsive.
I heard about this from constituents who were concerned about the young people who were confused and unsure about their status.
The department attended my committee . I want to thank them for coming.
One of the responsibilities we have is to provide oversight of our departments and how they function and provide service.
In order to ensure transparency about these mistakes, I invited the Department so we could hear about it and how they plan to prevent this from happening again.
The director indicated that in order to repair the harm done to the young people who sought to participate, they notified all the applicants that their proposals will be funded.
I am excited that young people will be able to participate in the grant program.
We had originally 17, the intent was to fund 17 awards.
We had 82 applicants in my understanding is that all 82 will receive some funding to support their projects.
The next committee meeting is Friday, February 25 at 9:30.
Moving on.

Part of the larger facility project . We went along with folks from the office of housing, arts Department--really to get a sense of how the space could be temporarily activated for community use . Finally, colleagues, I want to address the Eviction moratorium.
That we know has been a topic of conversation for the last several days, really for the last two years as the pandemic has taken a toll on our neighbors.
We know that low income Renter families have been particularly hard hit.
And are dealing with high stress.
Especially if they are folks who are deemed essential workers who have had to be out in their communities or who have experienced the hardship of the pandemic.
None of that has changed.
And certainly will not change by the end of February.
We know that Omicron is showing signs of slowing, but Nevertheless we still have over 300 cases a day in the city of Seattle.
Which is higher than we had prior to December of last year.
In March, Covid will still be here and people will still owe rent and neighbors will be still missing work.
And until Renters have had a chance to catch up on their rent debt, I think it is important for us to reconsider this decision.
Want to make sure that Renters understand their rights.
We have a winter Eviction ban that will be in place until March 31 and it will return on December 1. that provide some level of Eviction protection.
But we also have a similar emergency in place and that means two things.
There is a lot of talk about the 2020 ordinance that provides six months of defense following the end of the moratorium, Eviction moratorium.

But I want to remind folks that last year my office brought in this council passed legislation to insure a defense to Eviction for those with an inability to pay rent during this civil emergency and for the following six months.
I want folks to know that this is another layer of protection that does not end in February.
And it remains in place until six months after the Covid civil emergency ends.

Additionally, in 2020 my office brought and this council passed an update to the fair chance housing ordinance to insure that in most cases, if you are served an Eviction notice, if you are taken to court for an Eviction or evicted during the civil emergency, it is a Seattle fair housing violation, if a future landlord tries to use that to deny you housing.

These are not going to stop any trauma . But I folks to understand there is some additional protection for people . This is--if we end the moratorium at the end of the month that is not going to slow the potential surge in displacement and homelessness that could result . I want to urge the Mayor to reconsider the Eviction moratorium to allow it to extend past the end of February.
And give tenants a chance to catch up on rent, now that folks are at least somewhat able to go back to work.
That is all I have.

This morning, I joined about 50 members of teamsters 174.
Members have been on the strike line since Thanksgiving from Thanksgiving until Valentine's day, numbers in the concrete driver industry have been calling for a fair contract.
The teamster members have been on strike against six major concrete suppliers.
It has resulted in thousands of hours of not being able to be on job sites that are helping to rebuild our city and the workers want to be there.

In order to be on the job site, whether through sound transit jobs or building affordable housing or helping to supply concrete for the West Seattle bridge, the thing needed is a fair contract and the employers have not been coming to the table and bargaining in good faith as required by law.
This morning Congressman Smith was there and he said this standstill comes at the expense of people and hurts families.
The actions by the employer seem to indicate undermining unions then rather than negotiating in good faith.

By echo that sentiment and I share that this Council has heard supportive comments from workers and their right to be striking and we are rallying behind them to make sure they get a good contract and we get trained and skilled union members deploying concrete.
We want to make sure these union members from teamsters 174 have their contractor filled and we have the infrastructure met.
You can find out more on our Website.
We put information out about where to go to support the teamsters strike Fund.
Folks and donate if they are interested.

Court records show black cyclists from a decade ago were to be Ticketed for not having a and a decade later the disparity was about four times.
This is about racial equity and we will are to pass a resolution that talks about how we can do education and outreach that does not involve Seattle police Department.
